Literature Review: Lipids are a diverse group of biomolecules that play crucial roles in cellular function, including energy storage, membrane structure, and signaling. Their structural diversity and functional importance make them valuable biomarkers in both modern and ancient environments. This review explores the biogeochemistry of lipids, their biosynthesis and compartmentalization, their use as biomarkers, and the advancements in lipidomic techniques that have revolutionized the field. Lipid biogeochemistry encompasses the study of lipids in environmental contexts, particularly in marine systems. Lipids are synthesized by microorganisms and other organisms through complex biochemical pathways, resulting in a wide array of structures. These lipids are compartmentalized within cells, forming membranes and other structures that are essential for cell function. The composition of these lipids can vary significantly depending on the organism and environmental conditions, making them useful indicators of biological processes and environmental changes. In the context of microbial oceanography, lipids serve as biomarkers that can provide insights into the metabolic activities and community composition of microorganisms in the ocean. Advancements in lipidomic techniques have greatly enhanced our ability to study lipids in complex biological systems. However, the annotation of lipidomes remains a significant challenge. A case study on the lipidome of a marine microbial community illustrates the complexity and diversity of lipids in the ocean. The integration of lipidomics with other meta-omic approaches has also provided new insights into the interactions between microorganisms and their environment. In conclusion, lipid biogeochemistry and lipidomics are powerful tools for studying the biology and ecology of marine systems.
